entry.title: WWDC18 Scholarships Information
entry.content: Wait, before we start, what is WWDC? I‚Äôll add my description soon, but for now, check out the official website. Thank you all for being interested in Apple‚Äôs Worldwide Developer Conference and this scholarship opportunity. I hope all of us could go together, to learn, and have fun! I know this article is a little bit long, but please read through this carefully before you start. If you have any questions, just ask me through messenger, or in the comment area below. I‚Äôll be constantly updating this, and the Chinese version is available here. Important Dates Date Event April 1, 20:00 EDT Submission Due April 20 Announce Status June 3-8 Orientation + WWDC! General Information Please read the description carefully, as well as the terms and conditions. In summary, you are required to write a Playground ‚Äì an interactive program ‚Äì that is creative and technically accomplished. Things to Get You do NOT need a paid Apple Developer Account. Do you know what‚Äôs better than that? You‚Äôll get one year of Apple Developer membership if you win! If you have a Mac, download Xcode from Mac App Store, or if you have an iPad, download Swift Playgrounds from App Store, or if you have a Windows, get a virtual machine or whatever that works. Learn Swift If you have an iPad, I highly recommend you to go through one of those ‚ÄúLearn to Code‚Äù playgrounds to get a general idea about what a legit playground should be like, in addition to the Swift programming language itself. At the same time, everyone by now should have either an iOS device or a Mac, please open (i)Books and get The Swift Programming Language. You can always choose to read it online as well. Most of you are already familiar with Java, so reading just ‚ÄúA Swift Tour‚Äù should be adequate for you to understand this simple programming language. For those of you never learned programming before, just scan through that, and chapter 2 (Language Guide) will answer your questions. You do NOT need to read chapter 3 (Language Reference) and 4 (Revision History). General Stuff to Learn I Want to Write a 2D game You should learn SpriteKit. I Want to Write a 3D game You should learn SceneKit, but I hope you‚Äôve already had some sense of how 3D works and where to get your 3D models. A bonus for you, Apple talked about using SceneKit in the iPad version of Swift Playgrounds. Otherwise Well, UIKit itself can do a lot of stuff. To get started, follow Start Developing iOS Apps (Swift). If you have time, you may also want to have a general understanding of how view controllers work, maybe more about table views, or even iOS Apps in general. More About Playground No matter what, you should read the Markup Formatting Reference. Your Playground will look a lot better with this in conjunction with CustomPlaygroundQuickLookable/CustomPlaygroundDisplayConvertible. Mac, Xcode, and Playground It was first introduced back in 2014, and later in 2015 you can use the format mentioned above to author rich Playgrounds to better instruct your users. Here is a simple Swift Playground Book for you to get started, and you can also find other interesting ones from the Swift Blog, although many of them would be outdated and require some changes for them to work. iPad and Swift Playgrounds This app is first introduced in 2016 and updated again last year. iPad Playground has many features that a normal Xcode Playground doesn‚Äôt have ‚Äì Cut Scenes written in html (a great place to inform your user what‚Äôs this chapter about), cover images, vocab lists, etc. To fully utilize those features, please read the Playground Book Format Reference, and experiment with this sample that allows you to send messages to a Swift Playground live view and saving data to its key-value store. Analysis Remember that your playground will be judged offline, the program can NOT require an account for sign in, and they‚Äôll only spend 3 minutes in judging it, so think about what you are going to do. Even without thinking I can tell you many people will be doing augmented reality and machine learning; you can not imagine how easy it is to implement those fancy but scary stuff with ARKit and Core ML. Well, try to be creative, add some graphics and audios, and incorporate some of Apple‚Äôs new technologies (even if they didn‚Äôt mention about that)‚Ä¶ For the first time, you are allowed to use open source frameworks (providing that you included their licenses correctly and explained why). Nonetheless, what you are going to submit is not just a normal program. I think these are some reasons why Apple prefers Playground over normal apps, and maybe you want to address some of them: user will be directed about what to do and informed of what is expected it provide an interactive way for the users to learn things through programming it sparks users‚Äô interest in coding and encourages further participation ‚Ä¶(many more to add) Also, the ‚ÄúBeyond WWDC‚Äù essay is very important. You should explain, in 500 words, how you share your coding knowledge and enthusiasm for computer science with others. Spend some time on this and revise it several times. However, that doesn‚Äôt mean the playground itself isn‚Äôt important. There were many amazing playgrounds, such as this one here, but the quality of the other ones varies. So my suggestion is analysis why some of them got accepted and some got rejected, see if you can resonate with former winners, and just try your best. If you‚Äôd ever ask me if it‚Äôs hard, I‚Äôll answer yes but DOABLE. Just make sure you don‚Äôt copy any others‚Äô code ‚Äì the 2048 playground from last year‚Äôs submissions was rejected for this reason. Everything is doable if you try. Mr. Lau Good luck. ‚Äì Apollo (a.k.a Zhiyu Zhu, last year‚Äôs scholarship winner for submitting Karel the Robot Playground)

after what they did, I have to leave‚ÄùÔºåÂºπËµ∑‰∫ÜÁßØÁÅ∞ÁöÑÈí¢Áê¥ÔºåËøΩÂØª‰∏Ä‰∏ùÂπ≥Èùô„ÄÇ entry.title: ÊÑüÊÉ≥‰πãÂêéÂÜçË°•
entry.content: Any real change implies the breakup of the world as one has always known it, the loss of all that gave one an identity, the end of safety. And at such a moment, unable to see and not daring to imagine what the future will now bring forth, one clings to what one knew, or thought one knew; to what one possessed or dreamed that one possessed. Yet, it is only when a man is able, without bitterness or self-pity, to surrender a dream he has long cherished or a privilege he has long possessed that he is set free‚Äîhe has set himself free‚Äîfor higher dreams, for greater privileges. James Baldwin‚ÄúFaulkner and Desegregation‚ÄùNobody Knows My Name

entry.title: ËøôÊÄé‰πàÂèØËÉΩÊòØÁúüÁöÑÔºü
entry.content: 123if a == 1 && a == 2 && a == 3 { print("All three match!")} ËøôÊú¨Êù•ÊòØ‰∏™ JavaScript ÁöÑÈù¢ËØïÈ¢òÔºå‰ΩÜËøôÂπ∂‰∏çËÉΩÈòªÊ≠¢Êàë‰ª¨Âú®Êé®Áâπ‰∏äÁ†îÁ©∂ Swift ÈáåÁöÑËß£Ê≥ï„ÄÇ All three match ‚Äì how many ways can you think of to make this true in Swift? You‚Äôll learn by trying üëç pic.twitter.com/FTRh2uKhTb— Paul Hudson (@twostraws) 2018Âπ¥1Êúà20Êó• Êú¨Êñá‰∏çËÆ®ËÆ∫ Unicode ÊàñËóè‰ª£Á†ÅËøô‰∫õÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÇ ËÆ°ÁÆóÂûãÂèòÈáè ËøôÂèØËÉΩÊòØÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÊúÄÂÆπÊòìÊÉ≥Âà∞ÁöÑÔºåÂè™Ë¶ÅÊØèÊ¨°Ëá™Âä†‰∏ÄÂ∞±Â•Ω‰∫ÜÔºö 12345var _a = 0var a: Int { _a += 1 return _a} ÈáçËΩΩËøêÁÆóÁ¨¶ ÂèÇÊï∞ÂêçÂπ∂‰∏çÈáçË¶ÅÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êú¨ÊñáÈááÁî®Áªü‰∏ÄÁöÑ lhs Âíå rhs ÂΩìÁÑ∂Èô§‰∫ÜÊîπÂèòÈáè‰πãÂ§ñÔºåÊîπËøêÁÆóÁ¨¶‰πüÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÊÄùË∑ØÔºö 123456var a = 1func ==(lhs: inout Int, rhs: Int) -> Bool { // ‰∏çÂä† `inout` ÈÇ£ `lhs` Â∞±Êîπ‰∏∫ `a` defer { lhs += 1 } // `a = 0` Â∞±‰∏çÁî® `defer` return !(lhs != rhs) // ÈÅøÂÖçÈÄ†ÊàêÈÄíÂΩí} ÁÑ∂ÂêéÂ∞±Âá∫Áé∞‰∫ÜÊõ¥ÁÆÄÂçïÁ≤óÊö¥ÁöÑÔºö 123func &&(lhs: Bool, rhs: Bool) -> Bool { return true }// Â¶ÇÊûú T Â∑≤ÁªèÊòØ EquatableÔºåÈÇ£ÂøÖÈ°ªÂæóÊõøÊç¢ÊàêÊõ¥ÂáÜÁ°ÆÁöÑÁ±ªÂûãfunc ==<T>(lhs: T, rhs: Int) -> Bool { return true } ÈÅµÂæ™Êñ∞ÂçèËÆÆ Ëøô‰∏™ÊúâÁÇπÂèçÁùÄÊù•ÁöÑÊÑüËßâÔºåÁ°ÆÂÆû‰∏çÂÆπÊòìÊÉ≥Âà∞„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ©ÊüêÁßç Equatable ÈÅµÂæ™ ExpressibleByIntegerLiteral ÂçèËÆÆÔºåËøôÊ†∑ 1„ÄÅ2„ÄÅ3 Â∞±ËÉΩË¢´ËßÜ‰∏∫Âíå a ÊòØÂêå‰∏Ä‰∏™Á±ªÂûãÁöÑÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰πüÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•Ê¨∫È™óÂ∑≤ÁªèÂ≠òÂú®ÁöÑ ==ÔºåËÆ©‰ªñ‰ª¨Ë¢´ËßÜ‰∏∫Áõ∏Á≠âÁöÑÔºö 123456enum Foo: ExpressibleByIntegerLiteral { case bar public init(integerLiteral value: Int) { self = .bar }} ÊàñËÄÖÊàëËøô‰∏™ÊúâÁÇπÈáçÁé∞ C ËØ≠Á≥ªÊÑüËßâÁöÑÔºö 12345extension Bool: ExpressibleByIntegerLiteral { public init(integerLiteral value: Int) { self = value != 0 }} Ê•º‰∏ª‰∏≠ÈÄîÂèàÂä†‰∫Ü‰∏™ÈôêÂà∂ÔºåË¶ÅÊ±Ç‰ª£Á†ÅÂêåÊó∂Á¨¶ÂêàËøô‰∏™ËøêË°åÁªìÊûúÔºö 12345if b == 1 && b == 2 && b == 3 { print("All three match!") // ‰∏çÊâßË°åËøô‰∏ÄÊù°} else { print("All three don't match!")} ‰ΩÜËøôÂè™Ë¶Å a Âíå b ‰∏çÊòØÂêå‰∏Ä‰∏™Á±ªÂûã/ÂÆûÁé∞Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•‰∫ÜÔºåÊ≤°Âï•ÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇËÄå‰∏îÊàë‰ª¨ËøòÂèØ‰ª•Áî®Á±ª‰ºº‰∫éËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊù•Êé©‰∫∫ËÄ≥ÁõÆÔºö 12let a: Bool = 1, b = 1// ‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑ `b` ËøòÊòØ `Int` Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ËøòÊúâÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑÂßøÂäøÔºå‰∏çÂ¶®Âú®‰∏ãÈù¢ÔºåÂà∞ bilibiliÔºåÊàñËÄÖÂéª Êé®Áâπ ‰∏äÂõûÂ§ç„ÄÇ

entry.title: ‰ª§‰∫∫ËÑ∏ÊâÅÁöÑ macOS Á®ãÂ∫èÂõæÊ†áÊõøÊç¢
entry.content: ÊØïÁ´üÊòØ‰∫≤ÂÑøÂ≠êÔºåÁî® Swift ÂÆûÁé∞ËøêË°åÊó∂ÊõøÊç¢Á®ãÂ∫èÂõæÊ†áÔºåÊòØËàíÊúçÂæóËÑ∏ÊâÅÔºõ‰∏çËøáÁî® Java ÂÆûÁé∞ÔºåÈÇ£ÂèØÊòØÊÅºÁÅ´ÂæóËÑ∏ÊâÅ„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Áî® Swift Áî® Swift Âú® macOS ‰∏äÊääÂõæÊ†áÊõøÊç¢‰∏∫Âè¶‰∏ÄÂº†ÂõæÁâáÔºö 1NSApp.applicationIconImage = #imageLiteral(resourceName: "ÂõæÊ†áÁöÑÂêçÂ≠ó.png") Â¶ÇÊûúË¶ÅËÆæÁΩÆ‰∏∫ NSView ÁöÑËØùÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÔºö 1234// Â¶ÇÊûúÊúâÈúÄË¶ÅÂèØ‰ª•Ëé∑ÂæóÂõæÊ†áÁöÑÂ§ßÂ∞èÔºölet size = NSApp.dockTile.sizeNSApp.dockTile.contentView = <#T##‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂõæÊ†áÁöÑ NSView##NSView#>NSApp.dockTile.display() <##> ÊòØ Xcode ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂç†‰ΩçÁ¨¶ÁöÑÊ†ºÂºèÔºåÂ§ßÂÆ∂ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞ùËØï‰∏ã„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Áî® Java ‰Ω†ÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöËØ¥‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà‰∏çÁî® JFrame::setIconImage ÊàñËÄÖ add Âà∞ JavaFX ÁöÑ Stage.getIcons() Èáå‚Äî‚Äîna√Øve„ÄÇËôΩÁÑ∂‰ªñ‰ª¨‰∏çËÄÉËôë MacÔºå‰ΩÜÊàë‰ª¨‰∏∫‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁùÄÊÉ≥ÔºåÂú® Java ÂΩªÂ∫ïÊèêÂá∫Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à‰πãÂâçÔºå‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂÖºÂÆπÂÖ∂‰ªñÂπ≥Âè∞ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰ΩøÁî®ÂèçÂ∞ÑÂÆûÁé∞Ôºö 1234567try { Class NSApplication = Class.forName("com.apple.eawt.Application"); Method sharedApplication = NSApplication.getMethod("getApplication"); Object shared = sharedApplication.invoke(NSApplication); Method setApplicationIconImage = NSApplication.getMethod("setDockIconImage", java.awt.Image.class); setApplicationIconImage.invoke(shared, /*‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂõæÊ†áÁöÑ Image*/);} catch (Throwable ignored) { } ËôΩÁÑ∂ÈîôÁöÑÊòéÊòéÊòØ‰ªñ‰ª¨Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰∏äÈù¢ÊèêÂà∞ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂú® Java 9 ÔºàÊ≤°‰∫ãÂπ≤‰∏çË¶ÅÁî® Java 9Ôºâ‰∏ãËøòÊòØ‰ºöË¢´Ë≠¶ÂëäÁöÑÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫‰πãÂêé‰ºöÊúâËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇÈ°∫‰æøÊèê‰∏ÄÂè•ÔºåËôΩÁÑ∂Âõ†‰∏∫‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êËÇØÂÆöË¶Å try-catch ÊâÄ‰ª•Ê≤°ÊúâÂøÖË¶ÅÔºå‰ΩÜÂèØ‰ª•ËøôÊ†∑Âà§Êñ≠ÊòØ Mac Á≥ªÁªüÔºö 1System.getProperty("os.name").toLowerCase().contains("mac") ÊúâÂì™ÈáåÂÜôÈîô‰∫ÜËÆ∞ÂæóËÆ©ÊàëÂêåÊó∂Êõ¥Êñ∞ B Á´ô cv99301

entry.title: LeetCode - 2. Add Two Numbers
entry.content: Êú¨Êù•ËØ¥ LeetCode ÂáÜÂ§áÂÖ®Áî® SwiftÔºåÔºàËøôÈÅìÈ¢òÊ≠£Â∏∏ÂÅöÊ≥ï Swift ‰πüË°åÔºåËØ¶ËßÅÊ≠£Á°ÆÁ≠îÊ°àÔºâÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÊÉ≥ÂÅ∑ÊáíÔºåËøô‰∏™Êó∂ÂÄôÂè™ÊúâÈù† python ËøôÁßçÈÄÇÂêàÂ§ßÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÊâçË°åÔºåÊØïÁ´üËøôÈÅìÈ¢òÁöÑÊú¨Ë¥®ÊòØÊää‰∏§‰∏™Êï∞Áõ∏Âä†„ÄÇ You are given two non-empty linked lists representing two non-negative integers. The digits are stored in reverse order and each of their nodes contain a single digit. Add the two numbers and return it as a linked list. You may assume the two numbers do not contain any leading zero, except the number 0 itself. Input: (2 -> 4 -> 3) + (5 -> 6 -> 4) Output: 7 -> 0 -> 8 ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äËøôÂ∞±ÊòØËÆ°ÁÆó 342+465=807342 + 465 = 807342+465=807ÔºåÊØè‰∏™Êï∞Â≠óÂàÜÂà´ÊòØÂÄíÁùÄÂÜôÁöÑ„ÄÇÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÖà toInt ÈÄíÂΩíÊääÈìæË°®ËΩ¨Êç¢ÊàêÊï¥Êï∞ÔºåÁÑ∂Âêé toListNode ÊääÊï¥Êï∞ËΩ¨ÂõûÈìæË°®„ÄÇ‰ΩÜËøôÁßç‰∏çË¥üË¥£‰ªªÁöÑÂÜôÊ≥ï Swift ‰ºöÊ∫¢Âá∫Ôºå‰∫éÊòØÊç¢‰∫Ü python„ÄÇ 1234567891011toInt = lambda l: l and toInt(l.next) * 10 + l.val or 0def toListNode(i): base = None for c in str(i): new = ListNode(int(c)) new.next = base base = new return baseclass Solution: def addTwoNumbers(self, l1, l2): return toListNode(toInt(l1)+toInt(l2)) toListNode ÈáåËΩ¨Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÂÆåÂÖ®ÊòØ‰∏çÂæóÂ∑≤ËÄå‰∏∫„ÄÇÊàë‰∏ÄÂºÄÂßãÔºà‰πüÊòØ StefanPochmannÔºâÁî®ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÔºö 12345def toListNode(i): this = ListNode(i % 10) if n > 9: this.next = toListNode(i / 10) return this Êúâ‰∫õËπäË∑∑ÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂú®Êï∞Â≠óÂ§üÂ§ßÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºå‰ºöÂíåÊ≠£Á°ÆÁªìÊûúÊúâ‰∫õÂá∫ÂÖ•„ÄÇÂéüÂõ†‰∏çÊòéÔºåÈöæ‰∏çÊàêÊòØÈô§Ê≥ïÂ∏¶Êù•ÁöÑÊµÆÁÇπËØØÂ∑ÆÔºü

entry.title: Âú® Windows 10 ‰∏äË∑ë Swift
entry.content: ÊäõÂºÄÂ§ßÂ§öÊï∞Ëøû Swift ÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÈÉΩÊ≤°ÊúâÂê¨ËØ¥ËøáÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÁü•ÈÅì Swift ÁöÑ‰∫∫Â§ßÂ§öÈÉΩËßâÂæóÂÆÉÂè™ËÉΩÁî®‰∫é iOS ÂºÄÂèëÔºåÂÖ∂ÂÆû‰∏çÁÑ∂„ÄÇSwift Âú® 15 Âπ¥Â∫ïÂ∞±ÊîØÊåÅ‰∫Ü Windows Âíå AndroidÔºå‰∏çËøáÂõ†‰∏∫ÁºñËØëËøáÁ®ãËøá‰∫éÂ§çÊùÇÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Ê≤°ÊúâÊéÄËµ∑Â§™Â§ßÁöÑÊ∂üÊº™ÔºõÂèçÂÄíÊòØ 2017 Âπ¥Â§èÂ§©ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÂæÆËΩØÂÆ£Â∏ÉÊää Ubuntu Êê¨Ëøõ Windows ËÆ© Swift Êúâ‰∫ÜÂ§ßÊòæË∫´ÊâãÁöÑÊú∫‰ºö„ÄÇ ÈÖçÁΩÆ Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) ÊòØËøô‰∏ÄÂàáÁöÑÂü∫Á°ÄÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Êàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÂú® Windows 10 ‰∏äÂÆâË£Ö UbuntuÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÁî® bash ÂÆâË£Ö Swift ÁºñËØëÂô®„ÄÇÂèØÊÉúÁöÑÊòØ WSL Âπ∂‰∏çÊîØÊåÅ Swift ÁöÑ‰∫§‰∫íÂºèËß£ÈáäÂô®ÔºàREPLÔºâÔºåÂ∞ΩÁÆ°Â¶ÇÊ≠§Áº∫‰æùÁÑ∂Ë¶ÅÊ±Ç‰Ω†Êúâ ÁâàÊú¨ 1607 Âèä‰ª•‰∏ä ÁöÑ 64 ‰Ωç Windows 10ÔºàÂèØ‰ª•Âú® ËÆæÁΩÆ > Á≥ªÁªü > ÂÖ≥‰∫é ‰∏≠Êü•ÁúãÔºâ„ÄÇ Ê≠•È™§ Êàë‰ª¨ÂÖàË¶ÅÂêØÁî®ÈÄÇÁî®‰∫é Linux ÁöÑ Windows Â≠êÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ‰ª• ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂëò Ë∫´‰ªΩËøêË°å PowershellÔºåËæìÂÖ•‰ª•‰∏ãÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÄÇÂÆåÊàêÂêéÊåâ Y ÈáçÂêØÁîµËÑë„ÄÇ 1Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux ÊàñËÄÖÂèØ‰ª•Âú® ÊéßÂà∂Èù¢Êùø > Á®ãÂ∫è > ÂêØÁî®ÊàñÂÖ≥Èó≠ Windows ÂäüËÉΩ ‰∏≠ÔºåÂãæÈÄâ‚ÄúÈÄÇÁî®‰∫é Linux ÁöÑ Windows Â≠êÁ≥ªÁªü(Beta)‚ÄùÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÁÇπÁ°ÆÂÆö„ÄÇÊ†πÊçÆÊèêÁ§∫ÈáçÂêØ„ÄÇ ÈáçÂêØ‰ª•ÂêéÔºåÂêØÁî®ÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÊ®°Âºè„ÄÇ‰ª• ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂëò Ë∫´‰ªΩËøêË°å PowershellÔºåËæìÂÖ•‰ª•‰∏ãÂÜÖÂÆπÔºö 1reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\AppModelUnlock" /t REG_DWORD /f /v "AllowDevelopmentWithoutDevLicense" /d "1" ÊàñËÄÖÂèØ‰ª•Âú® ËÆæÁΩÆ > Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂíåÂÆâÂÖ® > entry.title: Advanced CS Student Survey
entry.content: Dear Advanced APCS students, In order to provide an excellent learning environment for you in this coming school year, I would like you to help me answer the following questions, be as specific and detailed as possible, so that I can do a better job in terms of fulfilling your needs. Thank you for your time. Mr. Lau Why did you sign up to take this course? Be specific. Just interested; to learn. What do you expect to learn from this course? If you know nothing about the curriculum, just brainstorm by yourself and tell me something that you want to learn. Fully understand Big-O notation. Basic algorithms and data structures, and when/why to choose one over another. What did you do over the summer that is related to computing (summer camp, internship, self-learning, taking an online course, teaching other people)? Please tell me what you learned through this experience. Be as specific as possible. Mainly translating Stanford‚Äôs Developing iOS 10 Apps with Swift; read The Swift Programming Language (Beta). Wrote an app to post the translated subtitle to online video platform, practiced using recursion, HTTP request, async background queue, and Continuous Integration. Wrote a raffle app in Kotlin (Google‚Äôs new programming language for Android, basically Java), refreshed memory of Swing, learned a little about JavaFX. Read part of the K&R (The C Programming Language). Watched a short series of basic tutorials about HTML & CSS. Watched How GitHub uses GitHub series. Learned several git commands. Please check those topics that you know something about. Tell me something about each if possible. [x] Linked List: Holding a pointer to the previous/next Element. Easier to add/remove, harder to find index. [x] Recursion: Using itself in the definition of itself. Throws StackOverFlowException. [ ] Big-O notation [x] Stack: First (push) In, Last (pop) Out. How I deal with recursive methods. [x] Queue: FIFO. [x] Priority Queue: Queue, elements ordered by priority. [x] Hash Table: AKA Dictionary<K: AnyHashable, V: AnyObject>, mapping Key to Value. [ ] Heap [x] Tree: Nodes. May traverse in Pre/In/Post order (if should visit root first). [x] Binary Search Tree: Each node has max 2 child, with left < this < right, and each child is BST [x] Graph: (Un)directed edges connecting vertices. [ ] Depth first search [ ] Breadth first search [ ] Quicksort (and basically all other sorting algorithms) Your concerns about this course. Be specific and honest. Write as much as necessary! Big-O notation sounds/is quite confusing, it took me a long time to understand why merge sort is O(nlogn).

entry.title: GitHub's Swift Style Guide
entry.content: ‰∏≠ÊñáÁâàÊú¨ When I was cleaning up my GitHub repos and stars, I found GitHub‚Äôs style guide for Swift, and I find this 2nd most starred style guide quite amusing. Despite the fact that Xcode defaults to using 4 spaces for indentation (and we can clearly see the impact by checking tabs-or-spaces), the style guide suggests using tabs instead. I‚Äôm totally fine with that, but I can easily tell there are some disagreements among the contributors: 1234567var myGreatProperty: Int { return 4}subscript(index: Int) -> T { return objects[index]} But there‚Äôs more. For now (2017 Auguest 23), there are three Swift repos under GitHub‚Äôs main account ‚Äì one source, two forks. Well, then let‚Äôs focus on SoftU2F, the ONLY Swift repository GitHub actually owns. Isn‚Äôt it natural for me to expect this repo to follow GitHub‚Äôs own style guide? But ironically, even SoftU2F is NOT doing that! In conclusion, seems that GitHub is not interested in styling their Swift code, and thus the GitHub community (or at least the 4k stargazers) has no actual intention to follow GitHub‚Äôs style guide, too.

entry.title: A "Good" Letter to Next Years' APCSA Students
entry.content: This letter was included into the summer packet with minor modifications 12for (Student student : APCSA.future.students) System.out.print("Hello "+ student.name); You‚Äôll learn about computer science and Java here. You won‚Äôt be learning about how to write visually attractive programs for the most of the times, but what you learn will empower you to write those programs with ease. This course is the prerequisites for all other CS courses, but why are you taking it? For me, I was here to learn. Despite the fact that I love programming, I‚Äôm afraid of computer science, especially those abstract algorithms. To prepare for this course, I read Think Java carefully. Mr. Lau suggested to read the first three chapters, I read it entirely. You can download it on your phone, and read it whenever you take your phone out. You don‚Äôt need a full time period, except for the exercises at the end of each chapter. You might find yourself unable to complete the exercise questions like me; if you do, just go back and read about that part again. There are no preferred answers to those questions, so any code that generates the same result are correct. But if you ever wonder, mine is on GitHub. Even with a significant amount of knowledge about programming, you can always find something new here, so don‚Äôt just assume you are omniscient. Java is advanced but primitive, stern but nonchalant, expressive yet confusing. Learning Java is like learning a foreign language, you have to practice using it. Thus, I strongly recommend starting the labs early. Similar to those exercises included in Think Java, there are no standard ways to implement them. Therefore, explain to your tutor how you choose to complete the task, don‚Äôt let them type the code for you. And you never want your friend to show you their program; it will limit your imagination. This course requires you to think logically, trace what‚Äôs going on. It is a frustrating process, but the good news is, you have a lot of resources. You can ask questions in class, take notes on or annotate important concepts for review. Another option is coming to Mr. Lau‚Äôs cougar time. You‚Äôll find a comfortable environment for studying computer science. If you have any questions, you can always ask Mr. Lau or students around you. A lot of ‚Äúgood‚Äù students and center tutors come on daily bases. They will always help you IFF you ask. Or join Oakton Computer Science Club, you‚Äôll find many opportunities to practice what you learned in this course, and meet with some really advanced students. You can be a good student too. It‚Äôs very simple: understand what you are doing. Never use a code snippet until you can write it and its variations out without any assistance. I‚Äôm definitely talking about plagiarism, but that‚Äôs not my focus. I want to emphasis on the importance of solving problems by yourself. If you can‚Äôt visualize the process in your head, draw a graph, a table, or a stack to visualize the flow of your program. If your program doesn‚Äôt compile, read the error messages. A lot of them doesn‚Äôt make any sense to you (and me), but you‚Äôll find the culprit through these traces. If you have a logic error, try break points. They are very easy to learn and convenient to use. You‚Äôll find them handy. Other than understanding how it works, you need to know why it works. You can achieve this by reading the source code of Java. Written by top developers in the world, Java source code demonstrates the conventions of writing Java code. You can compare your own solutions to theirs, and ask yourself what‚Äôs the difference. With a lot of documentations and comments, you can figure out why they choose to do it that way. Of course I‚Äôm not asking you to read all 2 billion lines of Java code, that‚Äôs neither necessary nor efficient. When Mr. Lau tell you ‚Äúthis is not natural,‚Äù it is a good place to start. If you have a professional IDE like Eclipse, just ctrl/command click on that method or class; otherwise, find it in the JAVA_HOME directory. A quick note for those ‚Äúgood‚Äù students. You may use ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù stuff ‚Äì such as regular expressions and lambdas ‚Äì in your lab. That‚Äôs what people use in real life, but make sure you know how to complete the tasks without those language features, fancy methods, and classes. Remember: ALL are equal before computer science; (to be) || !(to be), that is true. @ApolloZhu 2017/5/24

ÊÄªËÆ° 3164.7 Âπ≥Âù¶ 1070 Ëá¥Ë∞¢ ÊÑüË∞¢ Justin ÁöÑÂ¶àÂ¶àÂèäÊó∂Áªô Mr. Lau Âèë‰∫ÜÂ∞ÅÈÇÆ‰ª∂ËØ¥ÊòéÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÇÊàëÁõ∏‰ø°Ê≤°ÊúâÂ•πÁöÑÂ∏ÆÂä©ÔºåÂ∞±Ê≤°ÊúâÊàë‰ª¨ËøôÊ¨°ÁöÑÊóÖÁ®ã„ÄÇ‰ª•‰∏ãÊòØÂéüÊñáËäÇÈÄâÔºö Justin told me over the weekend that their group (Nithin Jonnalagadda, Zhiyu Zhu and Justin Li) has the opportunity to participate in this year‚Äôs ACSL All-Star Contest in southern California on May 27. I am very excited for them, and I think this is a very good experience for them to participate the activities outside school and see other students who share the same interest and passion with them from all over the country. My husband will be happy to be the chaperone. I have already purchased the air tickets for the four of them, reserved the hotel rooms, and rented a car last night. I would like to know if there is anything else that needs to be done to participate in this event to represent Oakton High School (like certain forms, school permissions, etc.). Last, I would like to thank you for acting as the group‚Äôs mentor and guiding them for the past two years. I am pretty sure they would not have been able to make it without your help. Looking forward to what these boys can achieve as they continue on! entry.title: Exam Appendix -- Java Quick Reference
entry.content: Accessible methods from the Java library that may be included on the exam 1234class java.lang.Object { boolean equals(Object other); String toString();} 12345678class java.lang.Integer { Integer(int value); int intValue(); /** Minimum value represented by an `int` or `Integer`. */ static int MIN_VALUE; /** Maximum value represented by an `int` or `Integer`. */ static int MAX_VALUE;} 1234class java.lang.Double { Double(double value); double doubleValue();} 1234567891011class java.lang.String implements java.lang.Comparable<String> { int length(); /** @return the substring beginning at `from` and ending at `to-1`. Note: the substring has length of `to - from`. */ String substring(int from, int to); /** @return `substring(from, length())`. */ String substring(int from); /** @return the index of the first occurrence of `str`; -1 if not found. */ int indexOf(String str); /** @return value < 0 if `this` less than `other`; 0 if equals to `other`; > 0 if greater than `other`. Note: According to ACSII. */ int compareTo(String other);} 1234567class java.lang.Math { static int abs(int x); static double abs(double x); static double pow(double base, double exponent); static double sqrt(double x); static double random();} 123456789101112interface java.util.List<E> { int size(); /** Appends obj to end of list. @return `true` Note: only if operation allowed, such as always true for `ArrayList`. */ boolean add(E obj); /** Inserts `obj` at position `index`, for 0 ‚â§ `index` ‚â§ `size()`. */ void add(int index, E obj) E get(int index); /** Replaces the element at position `index` with `obj`. @return the element formerly at the specified position. */ E set(int index, E obj); /** Removes element from position `index`, moving elements at position `index + 1` and higher to the left by 1 (subtracts 1 from their indices) and adjusts size. @return the element formerly at the specified position. */ E remove(int index);} 1class java.util.ArrayList<E> implements java.util.List<E> { }

entry.content: ÁõÆÂâçÂåÖÊã¨ÔºöÈÄâÊã©ÊéíÂ∫èÔºåÊèíÂÖ•ÊéíÂ∫èÔºåÂΩíÂπ∂ÊéíÂ∫è ÊÉÖÊôØÔºöÂ∞ÜÊï∞ÁªÑ a ‰∏≠ÁöÑ nnn ‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞‰ªéÂ∞èÂà∞Â§ßÊéíÂ∫è 123456int[] a;void swap(int[] a, int i, int j) { int temp = a[i]; a[i] = a[j]; a[j] = temp;} ÈÄâÊã©ÊéíÂ∫è ÊØîËæÉÊ¨°Êï∞Ôºön(n‚àí1)2\frac{n(n-1)}{2}2n(n‚àí1)‚Äã Êó∂Èó¥Â§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ÔºöO(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) ÈÄâÊã©ÊúÄÂ∞è 1234567for (int i=0;i<a.length-1;i++) { int minIndex = i; for (int j=i+1;j<a.length;j++) if (a[j] < a[minIndex]) minIndex = j; swap(a, minIndex, i);} ÈÄâÊã©ÊúÄÂ§ß 1234567for (int i=0;i<a.length-1;i++) { int maxIndex = i; for (int j=0;j<a.length-i;j++) if (a[j] > a[maxIndex]) maxIndex = j; swap(a, maxIndex, i);} ÊèíÂÖ•ÊéíÂ∫è Êó∂Èó¥Â§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ÔºöO(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) 123456for (int i=1;i<a.length;i++) { int cur = a[i], newIdx = i; while (newIdx > 0 && a[newIdx-1] > cur) a[newIdx] = a[--newIdx]; a[newIdx] = cur;} ÂΩíÂπ∂ÊéíÂ∫è Êó∂Èó¥Â§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ÔºöO(nlogn)O(n\,logn)O(nlogn) 123456789101112131415161718192021222324void mergeSort(int[] a) { mergeSort(a, 0, a.length-1);}void mergeSort(int[] a, int start, int end) { if (start >= end) return; int mid = (start+end)/2, i = start, j = mid+1, len = end-start+1, temp[] = new int[len]; mergeSort(a, i, mid); mergeSort(a, j, end); for (int k=0;k<len;k++) if (j>end || i<=mid && a[i]<a[j]) temp[k] = a[i++]; else temp[k] = a[j++]; for (int k=0;k<len;k++) a[start+k] = temp[k];}

entry.title: YearglassÔºèÂπ¥ËΩÆÈ°πÁõÆ
entry.content: ÊÑøËÉΩ‰∏∫ÂêõÔºåÊöÇÁïôÂÖâÈò¥ const today = new Date(); const year = today.getFullYear(); const thisYear = new Date(year, 0, 1); const nextYear = new Date(year + 1, 0, 1); const oneDay = today.getMilliseconds(); const passed = Math.floor((today - thisYear) / oneDay); const total = Math.floor((nextYear - thisYear) / oneDay); const percentage = passed / total; const space = 15; function repeat(s, n) { return new Array(Math.floor(n + 1)).join(s); } document.getElementById("yearglass-web").innerHTML = year + " Âπ¥Â∑≤ËøáÂéª " + Math.floor(percentage * 100) + "% [" + repeat("‚ñá", space * percentage) + repeat("\\\\", space * (1 - percentage)) + "]"; For the English Version of this documentation, please visit: yearglass Âú®Âç≥ÂàªÔºèÂæÆÂçöÔºèÊé®Áâπ‰∏äÁúãÂà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúâË∂£ÁöÑÊèêÈÜíÔºåyear_progressÔºåÊÄªÁöÑÊù•ËØ¥Â∞±ÊòØÊòæÁ§∫‰ªäÂπ¥ËøáÂéª‰∫ÜÁöÑÁôæÂàÜÊØî„ÄÇ‰∫éÊòØÈ°∫ÊâãÂ∞±Áî® Swift ÂÆûÁé∞‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁªàÁ´ØÁöÑÂ∞èÁ®ãÂ∫èÔºöÂπ¥ËΩÆ„ÄÇÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄô 2017 Âπ¥ÊâçËøáÂéª 17% Âë¢„ÄÇ Âü∫Êú¨ ‰∏ãËΩΩ 1git clone https://github.com/ApolloZhu/yearglass.git Êõ¥Êñ∞ 1cd yearglass;git pull;cd .. Âç∏ËΩΩ Âç∏ËΩΩÂÆåÊàêÂêéËøòÈúÄÊâãÂä®Âà†Èô§ÈÖçÁΩÆÔºåËØ∑ÂèÇËÄÉ‰∏ãÊñá„ÄÇ 1rm -rf yearglass Terminal ÈÖçÁΩÆ Âä†ÂÖ•Âà∞ÁªàÁ´ØÂêØÂä®ÂàóË°® 1echo "swift ~/yearglass/main.swift" >> .bash_profile Ê≥®ÂÜå yearglass ÂëΩ‰ª§ 1echo "alias yearglass='swift ~/yearglass/main.swift'" >> .bash_profile Âà†Èô§ÈÖçÁΩÆ 1sed -i '' '/swift .*yearglass.main.swift/d' .bash_profile Oh My Zsh ÈÖçÁΩÆ Êú¨‰∫∫Âπ∂‰∏ç‰∫ÜËß£ zsh ÊÄé‰πàÁî®ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊúâÁñèÊºèËøòËØ∑Â§ßÂÆ∂ÊåáÊ≠£„ÄÇ Âä†ÂÖ•Âà∞ÁªàÁ´ØÂêØÂä®ÂàóË°® 1echo "swift ~/yearglass/main.swift" >> .zshrc Ê≥®ÂÜå yearglass ÂëΩ‰ª§ 1echo "alias yearglass='swift ~/yearglass/main.swift'" >> .zshrc Âà†Èô§ÈÖçÁΩÆ 1sed -i '' '/swift .*yearglass.main.swift/d' .zshrc
